description: Minimal episode fixture for tests. Contains fields needed for interlude, scoreboard, FT detection.

segments.text: Welcome to Match of the Dead.
This weekend, the nation remembers those who lost their lives
while serving their country.
Football paid its respects.
Five Premier League games coming up on tonight's Match of the Day.
Slightly later than usual,
but Alan Shearer and Theo Walcott are well worth staying up for.
Or so they say.
Leaders Arsenal had won five in a row in the league,
the last four without conceding.
They'd made the trip to Sunderland,
who are unbeaten at home this season.
Guy Mowbray was at the Stadium of Light.
It's the biggest test yet of Sunderland's so far sound Premier League credentials,
as Arsenal come here seeking an 11th straight win across all competitions,
a run they last managed seven years ago.
Grenit Xhaka was in that Arsenal team,
but now leads Sunderland against his old club,
fresh from scoring his first goal for his new team on Monday.
And it's an unchanged line-up from the 1-1 draw with Everton.
There's one change for the Arsenal side that won at Burnley a week ago,
with Mikel Moreno deputising up front
for the injured Victor Llocares,
having scored twice doing it,
away to Slavia Prague on Tuesday.
Martin Zubimendi missed that game through suspension,
but he's back in today.
Arsenal's first visit to Wearside for just over nine years.
They won 4-1 last time.
They haven't been beaten in any of their last five here.
There's a tross-up with him, and Moreno has been hurt.
There was a clash of heads there in great force,
and the ref will have to stop the game.
Not a clash of heads.
Ballard won it cleanly.
His arm went into the right-hand side of Moreno's cheek there.
Nothing wrong with the challenge.
The arm's got to go up for balance.
Regis Lebris has called it pretty simply in his pre-match words.
We have to do a masterclass.
No choice.
Le Fay, time to bring it down, but he's given it away to Eze now.
And Eze has cleared the crossbar.
Sunderland can't give Arsenal presents.
They will make the most of it.
They will make the most of one before long.
Left Siddiqui wrong-footed.
I would think, given that opportunity again,
Eze would opt for something a bit more powerful.
Eze holds off Xhaka, but then Hume gets his foot to the ball.
Timber against Le Fay.
Le Fay on the floor.
And Isidore trying to break round the back.
Why? But it was a, well, if not a half chance, a third of a chance perhaps.
Isidore never really had the angle, but he certainly has the confidence.
Timber.
Saka.
He's started to get more and more involved.
Eze.
He takes a barge from Xhaka and complains about it, as did Arteta.
And there'll be more complaining now because the free kick's gone against his team.
Not only that, Zubi Mendy is the first player to get a booking.
Game clattering into Isidore.
Proofs to play it up towards Ballard.
There again.
Still concede a goal for the first time in nine games.
And who scored it?
Dan Ballard started out as a goalie.
It was an Arsenal junior.
Didn't make the breakthrough.
He has here tonight.
Sunderland won Arsenal nil.
Regis Lebris' game plan is working.
Get into Arsenal faces.
Rough them up a bit and upset them.
They're really upset now.
One thing for sure.
This Arsenal team has steel and they won't lie down.
Trossard.
He finds Saka.
And Saka plays it across the face.
But that was promising for Arsenal.
It hasn't happened too often at all today.
But on that occasion they were playing it nicely through
and finding the spaces in the penalty area.
Rice is on him.
Wins the ball.
Trossard's arriving.
Here's Saka.
First on the scene.
And Saka squeezing it in.
Coming since the start of the second half.
Enzo Lepe.
Not the first to be guilty of dallying in possession in his own half.
But he's the first to be made to pay for it.
Great work by Declan Rice.
We expect that from him.
And we expect this from Bakayo Saka.
Sunderland 1, Arsenal 1.
Trey Hume away.
Nice ball in for Zubi Mendy.
Chance after Arsenal chance coming now.
Through the legs of Bertrand Traore.
Zubi Mendy perfectly aware of his whereabouts there.
Knew he had to take it first time.
Rice.
Saka.
Roos punches but straight to Zubi Mendy.
Here's Eze now.
Breaking from Zubi Mendy's effort.
Not decisive Robin Roos.
Really good effort from Zubi Mendy.
Arsenal getting closer and closer all the time.
Trossard.
Space opens up for Trossard.
Now!
Oh that is fantastic.
Just managed to move the ball sufficiently far away from Noah Siddiqui.
To set himself up.
But he still had an awful lot to do from that point.
It has still got to be a perfect shot to get past Robin Roos from that range.
It is perfect.
And it's Sunderland 1 Arsenal 2.
And it gives Sunderland a free kick.
It's Hume.
Really good delivery.
Oh Odingra.
Gets the ball.
Mukiele was in his way a fraction of a second too long.
And now it's out.
Where's it going to be?
It's Sunderland's throw in.
Assistance from Mourinho and now with assistance from the black.
It was actually helped on by William Saliba.
Spooned by Raya who had a second grab at it.
It looked at that point as though Brogliev.
Brogliev would score.
But that's a really good save by Raya.
Mukiele.
To Rice.
But it bounced off him to Xhaka.
Hume.
It's over.
Brogliev.
Arriving in.
And it's Ranildo.
Went hurtling into the back of William Saliba.
Siddiqui.
Is in between him and the goal.
Hume.
Super finish from Brian Brogliev.
From the Sunderland centre back.
That sums him up.
That sums them up.
They just need a foul.
A long throw.
A direct ball.
To create that chaos.
You have to defend the action as well.
We lose the timing of that.
And we concede the goal.
So very disappointed.
Because even at the end in the last minute we have again a massive chance with Ricky and Mikkel to win it.
And it didn't mean to be.
So we have to accept it.
Difficult game.
Difficult environment to play in.
We've done extremely well.
Especially in the second half.
To come back and to put in the performance we put in.
But yeah.
We'll go into the international break.
Top of the league.
And we'll keep a bit of perspective.
Did the block at the end mean as much if not more than the goal you scored?
The stage of the game.
I mean if we conceded there it would have been a huge blow.
So it probably meant more in the end.
But there's no feeling not scoring a goal.
It was a tough game.
As expected.
Because we knew before that we faced probably one of the best teams in Europe.
I think now we have this faith.
This belief that until the final whistle anything is possible.
And Sunderland have shown all season that anything is possible.
They could have gone second if they had won this game.
They're unbeaten at home.
What was so impressive about this performance against Arsenal, Alan?
Well, particularly Dan Ballard.
I think he epitomised everything that Sunderland have done so well.
Particularly at home this season with his aggression.
With him and his teammates stopping Arsenal playing.
Particularly in that first half.
And they are really, really tough to play against.
And there were so many examples of that today.
With him and other players putting their body on the line for their team.
And for the atmosphere.
And I said he sort of summed everything up.
We're going to talk about this after.
But look how difficult it is to get through.
How many players they've got behind the ball.
And then I think that's really good defending.
As I said we'll talk more in a minute about that.
But that is really, really tough aggressive defending.
Then he...
Sunderland plays his part with this.
He makes it difficult to clear.
But have a look at the touch and the finish.
Goodness me.
Any forward would be proud of that finish.
Then when they're piling the pressure on.
He makes it really difficult there.
The flick on.
In for Brian Brobbey.
Who then finishes off with a great finish.
But it starts with him being aggressive in the box.
And not letting the Arsenal players defend the way they want to.
And then they get the reward.
And then Arsenal come back at them.
Straight down the other end.
And I said putting your body on the line for your team.
That's exactly what I mean.
And that's why it means so much to him as the defender to stop in that.
And you can see the reaction from all the fans from behind the goal.
And Arsenal will not have many tougher games than that this season.
I promise you.
And you can see he started his career at the Arsenal Academy.
And what a performance.
Him and Sunderland put in today.
I thought they thoroughly deserved the point.
Dan Ballard, player of the match.
But you mentioned that challenge on Mourinho.
They looked at it.
VAR looked at it.
And decided there was nothing to see there.
What was your view on it, Theo?
Well, my view.
I look at it a little bit differently, to be honest.
And it's not clear and obvious.
However, it's early in the game.
It's seven minutes in the game.
And Don Ballard, of course, wants to put his mark on the game.
Shall we just call it.
And Mikel Arteta spoke about being disruptive.
And he's definitely, from my opinion, right.
He's disruptive.
And there's a slight movement from the outside.
From the elbow to Mourinho's cheekbone.
Me and Al definitely probably don't agree on it.
However, I do feel like his elbow is in quite a high condition.
Shall we just call it.
And it was very disruptive.
And it did set the balance.
I think as a defender, if he allows that forward to get across him,
Mourinho, his manager goes absolutely berserk at him.
That's his space.
And he cannot allow any forward to get across him.
So, he then settles himself.
And then he goes for the header.
He can't jump without doing that for a header.
And I don't think there's anything deliberate about that.
I think it's more brilliant defending than anything else.
And you would have done that if you were challenging for the ball as a striker.
I wouldn't allow anyone to sort of get in me.
Or in and around me.
Or in front of me.
And that's his job as a defender.
He cannot allow the forward to get in front of him.
And he didn't.
Theo, as Alan was saying earlier, Sunderland's game plan worked perfectly.
Particularly in the first half.
But what changed for us on the second half?
What changed?
Mikel Arteta got into the dressing room first of all.
First before the players.
And the intensity was the biggest challenge.
That they had to face.
Because they were up against a very tough Sunderland team.
Who hadn't been beaten at home this year.
And the numbers they committed forward as well.
At times.
Because Saka was finding it hard in the first half to get involved in the game.
But this is what I'm talking about.
The bravery of committing bodies forward.
Declan Rice always starts the press.
And if you give Arsenal an opportunity, they're going to punish you.
Simple as that.
And you can't afford to do that.
Because Sunderland worked tremendously hard.
Al spoke a couple of weeks ago about the full backs committing forward.
And putting them in positions.
Where you don't really expect.
But this is what we're talking about.
The difference.
The bravery.
The committing the bodies forward.
Like I said before.
And this is where I felt at times.
Arsenal were always going to cause problems.
And make chances out of nothing.
There's a little bit of a snapshot here.
But this was the danger.
This is the warning signs that Sunderland had to be aware of.
Zubin Mendy I felt was absolutely brilliant in the second half.
Just a bit unlucky here of course.
But this is the luck that Arsenal probably get in this season.
Because they don't give up.
They don't give you many opportunities.
And Leon de Trossard for me is a player that is probably at times.
You know there's been questions.
But you can just see here.
Siddiqui points to Hume to say.
Look you take him.
But I don't understand why you would then step.
And give that opportunity.
That space to Trossard.
Particularly coming inside.
And you can see how disappointed he is.
It's a fantastic finish.
Not taking a finish away.
But look.
Leon de Trossard has come up from very, very important goals.
Right now for Arsenal Football Club.
And I think it's a really good point in the end.
To be honest with you.
When I look at it.
It's a balanced game.
I think Sunderland probably deserves something out of the game.
But Arsenal as well.
Alan they'll be looking at Manchester City, Liverpool tomorrow.
On Match of the Day.
What difference does that Arsenal result make to that game?
I agree with Theo.
I think in the grand scheme of things.
The way it was today.
And how tough it is for teams going to Sunderland.
I think it points a decent result.
And they'll be hoping that those two draw tomorrow.
Now Manchester United are unbeaten in their last four in the Premier League.
Ruben Amirim's joint best run since taking over.
They've travelled to Spurs.
And Steve Wilson watched this one.
Spurs in the top six of the Premier League.
Unbeaten in the Champions League.
A trophy in the Cabinet.
And yet.
And yet home is where the hurt is for Tottenham.
Who've won just three of their last 19 league games here.
Spurs fans are still buzzing about Nicky van de Ven's midweek wonder goal in Europe.
He scored twice as many as Richarlison this season.
No Europe for United of course.
They lost four times to Tottenham last term.
Including Europa League final.
A start for Masraoui.
Sheshko drops to the bench.
Europa League final they served up in Bilbao.
It was really a save our season match for both.
But the manager who won it lost his job.
The manager who lost it didn't.
Richarlison took it away from his countrymen.
Xabi Simon skipping forward with real purpose here.
That's unlucky.
It's a slip but it's taken up by Colomwani.
Blocked by De Ligt.
Casemiro.
And Bruno Fernandes.
And United have a counter attack here of some promise.
Cunha.
Getting through Romero.
Taken up by Bruno Fernandes.
And Bermo in behind.
Pedro Porro.
Well he had every right to think that somebody would be there but they weren't.
The flag has gone up anyway as it happens.
Four forward for United.
Spurs desperately trying to get bodies back.
That is super close.
If that ended up in the back of the net.
It would have been a long old VAR check.
Nice little dummy by Brian and Bermo.
Bruno Fernandes in behind.
Looking for Mathias Cunha.
And Bermo heads for the area.
Bruno Fernandes there too.
And a momentary position of interest.
He's not quite snuffed out.
Cunha's back heel.
Door goes crossed.
And Bermo's header.
Jed Spence with Amman.
Masraoui.
Amman's cross.
And in.
Brian and Bermo scores.
For Manchester United.
Again.
He is in a rich vein of form.
Scored at Anfield.
Scored two at home to Brighton.
And scores at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.
Brian and Bermo.
And that is far too easy.
And Bermo just standing there.
And no one gets close.
It's a very poor goal as you can see.
Manchester United.
Won't care.
And are in front.
Looks like Tottenham have actually gone to a back three.
With Johnson as a right wing back.
And Spence as a left wing back.
Johnson.
Pedro Porro's ball in.
It's a glance to Jean-Paulinho.
Never quite had it under control.
Blocked by Masraoui.
Spurs will have a throw in.
Here's Jed Spence.
Alderweireld.
That's a better ball in.
It's a really good save by Lambert.
Lamberts.
It's Tottenham's first attempt on target in the game.
And Christian Romero is denied.
Good stop by Senna-Lamberts because it's a very close ball to this.
Simons.
Mathias Cunha.
Simons has won that well.
He's being fouled by Mathias Cunha.
It's a free kick.
Must have been quite close to a yellow card that actually for Mathias Cunha.
But I think he's got away with it.
Pedro Porro for Spence.
Looking for Romero in the crowd.
It's Jean-Paulinho.
Lamberts there again.
Well the early impressions of Senna-Lamberts in a Manchester United jersey have been pretty good.
That's another smart save.
Might have seen that late.
It's going right through the legs of Harry Maguire.
Xavi Simons is being withdrawn and that is not a popular decision with the Tottenham fans.
Not at all.
Mathias Tell comes on.
Xavi Simons makes way.
Bruno Fernandes.
Oddibeck.
Udogi.
And Tell!
Minutes to go.
It's Tell with the goal for Spurs.
Pretty certain there's a deflection on this which helped it past Lamberts.
Tell with a neat turn.
And it's slicked off the toe actually of De Ligt and into the roof of the net.
The bit of luck that Tottenham badly required.
And it's won all in a game which frankly neither side really deserves to win.
Flick on Mason Mount here for Manchester United.
And the little ball into Benjamin Szczesko!
And a great sliding Van de Ven intervention keeps Tottenham level.
Szczesko is injured here.
Well this is what happened. Van de Ven brilliant.
They're not going to be able to replace him.
They've made five substitutions Manchester United.
Unless Szczesko can recover.
But it doesn't look like they're going to take that risk.
So it's one each.
Manchester United are a man short.
It's going to be a minimum of six added minutes.
Spence with the cross to Ligt behind.
Tottenham corner.
In goes the corner kick. Glanced away.
Oddibeck.
Garlison's head!
It's some turnaround.
Been almost no points.
In this game that you could have imagined Tottenham would win it.
But here we are in the 92nd minute and they're in front.
Richarlison with what is very likely to be the winning goal.
Well Oddibeck's effort is excellent.
And Richarlison I think meant it.
Tottenham 2 Manchester United 1.
Well their unbeaten sequence would seem to be coming to an end.
It's deflected.
And Manchester United will have a corner.
And Lammens the goalkeeper is coming forward.
In goes the United corner kick.
And De Ligt puts it in the net.
It's another terrible goal to concede from Tottenham's point of view.
But Manchester United have got themselves on level terms.
Mathis De Ligt.
Goodness me.
Luke Shaw did a good job for him just blocking Bentancur.
Which meant that De Ligt.
From close quarters.
Had no one in attendance.
And it's 2-2.
Amarim is prowling.
Manchester United's ten men remember.
And that is the final whistle.
Almost impossibly high drama at the end.
Very low quality before it.
But it finishes two each.
I think if you look at the game it was there.
The three points was there to take.
You can feel the environment.
We were comfortable in the game.
I think we can be so much better.
And to understand what's happened in the game.
But we fight in every adversity.
We lost Terry Maguire.
We lost Casemiro with pain.
We lost Sesco.
We suffered two goals.
And we managed to draw the game.
And that is a good sign.
Of course.
Of course it's not that I'm going away from here.
And not be disappointed when you're leading 2-1.
With one minute to go.
And you don't win.
That will always be the case.
To stay in the game.
Do the right thing.
Keep pushing.
Because in games like this where two teams are neutralizing a little bit.
You don't create so much.
That's natural.
But how the boys kept fighting.
Kept doing the right thing.
I was thinking it was hugely impressive.
I will stay positive.
Because the reaction in the second half was very, very good.
We showed a great mentality.
So I'm very happy to score this goal and help my team.
And I think we need to stay positive on this game.
It did improve as the game went on, Tottenham, Theo.
Did Thomas Frank get his substitutions right?
I don't think the Tottenham fans felt he got the substitutions right
when he made them, to be honest.
But what he did do was he created a...
They were getting too predictable, I felt.
Tottenham in the first half.
And you can see here.
First half compared to the second half.
Where all the players on the right-hand side were actually
Manchester United were very strong.
And the big part for that was Oduba.
Oduba was absolutely outstanding when he came on.
A player that...
Who has to be able to take risks.
And play with that freedom.
And the energy.
And that's what you have to do as a substitute.
You need to be able to commit bodies.
But what I like about him, he likes to put the ball in when you have space.
He likes to change his game.
And this is what I'm talking about.
Not being predictable.
When you give players who are ball-carriers in this amount of space,
Manchester United start dropping.
And Dogi was fantastic as well.
All three substitutions who came on actually contributed.
And Tell, just watch the finish, the spin.
Gets a bit of luck with the deflection.
However, it's the hard work that counts.
Oduba again outside on the...
Isolating Ahmad.
Who I felt defensively struggled when Maserati actually went off the field.
I felt Oduba probably got hit into the game a lot more.
And that created the corner.
And Oduba comes out, of course, more space.
And just has to guide it in for Charleston.
But it's fantastic.
And it just shows, trust the manager's process.
I think that's one thing.
As fans, when you watch games, you're always frustrated in the moment.
However, look, they're there for a reason.
Thomas Frank is a good manager.
He knows exactly what he's doing.
And he's made the right decision.
Having said that, on the flip side,
not all of Manchester United's substitutions worked perfectly.
Certainly one in particular, Alan.
Yeah, Sheshko struggled again.
He's only scored twice in his 12 appearances.
And he came on today with just over half an hour to go
and had two really, really good chances.
And should have scored, to be honest.
They worked really well, Man United,
for him to get in there with a one-and-two touch.
And that's a good ball in behind.
Now, he's either got to get his shot away early,
or he's got to push that ball forward quicker.
He's not going to get that amount of time in the Premier League
to work it and try and get it back onto his right foot.
This one's the bigger puzzle for me.
I know he was struggling for confidence.
But any centre-forward knows you cannot allow the forward,
the centre-half, to come back at you.
He's got to get across Van de Ven.
So if Van de Ven's going to tackle him, he makes sure he fouls them.
And you should also, by that time, have a picture in your head
of where the keeper is and what you are wanting to do.
And I don't think he has a clue what he wants to do.
Because I don't think he even knows Van de Ven is there and chasing him.
So now he should be looking at the keeper, thinking,
what am I going to do, where am I going to go?
And he wants to work it again. He's got to come across again.
He's trying to work it onto his right foot.
But, as I said, he has to get across or take it onto his left foot to finish.
There's not once he knows that Van de Ven is actually tracking him
and chasing him and preparing for that.
He's got to put a tackle in. He's got to get his shot away.
I know, as I said, he's struggling with confidence.
But it's a big must-do better.
And no-one likes to see him coming off injured.
And we hope his knee is OK.
But they are two chances that you'd expect at that level
that someone has to put away.
Thomas Frank was saying, obviously, you're going to be disappointed
when you concede that late on in a game when you've been leading 2-1.
But their home record, Tottenham, is so poor
and has been since before Thomas Frank as well.
When you look at the results since the start of 2025,
they are bottom of that particular...
Well, I think what they have to get used to now under Thomas Frank
is that teams are going to come to their stadium
and they're going to sit and defend
and then they've got to try and find and work their way out,
whereas when Tottenham are going away from home,
teams will attack them and that suits them better.
As for Manchester United, injuries are going to be a problem
continuing for them and there were more in today's game, Theo.
Yeah, no, of course, but, look, the international break
always comes at a good time for certain clubs,
but certainly right now it's come at a good time for United.
Yeah.
Now, last weekend's win against Newcastle was West Ham's first
since Nuno Espirito Santo took over
and their first at home this season.
Burnley were the visitors this time,
looking for back-to-back away wins.
Your commentator, Jonathan Pearce.
Despite last weekend's win over Newcastle,
once again West Ham fans have stayed to protest
against the club hierarchy with a petition calling for David Sullivan
and Karen Brady to step down, reportedly signed by more than 16,000,
and the West Ham fan advisory board passing a vote of no confidence in the board.
There were definite signs of improvement last week
for Nuno Espirito Santo's side,
who were looking for back-to-back wins for the first time since February
and, unsurprisingly, they're unchanged.
Jarrett Bowen plays his 250th game for the club.
Burnley make one change from the home defeat by Arsenal
and revert to a back four by bringing in Loom Chonok
and rotating Laurent to the bench.
And Burnley have won just two of the last 11 top-flight away games against West Ham.
So the Omens favour the home side,
but you never know with West Ham.
Walker goes long...
...for Quilinci Hartman, it's a good ball in the middle!
Really well played that, Burnley.
Just too far ahead of Jan Fleming.
From 15 yards inside their own half,
they were inside the West Ham six-yard box with two touches.
Scott Parker, five years as a player here
between his Newcastle and Tottenham days,
won the Footballer of the Year award while he was here,
and the England Player of the Year award as well.
129 games for West Ham.
Hartman, long up to Fleming, who did well.
Chonok...
Nice cross in, lovely head-up,
West Ham have seven defenders back in the box.
And yet it was far too easy for Ziyech.
And Fleming to head home, his fourth of the season.
Big question was Fleming onside.
As he heads back, Chonok,
then rolls it wide to Uguchukwu.
This is a measured, lovely bending cross.
Straight onto his forehead.
Good centre-forward header.
They're checking though for offside,
and my first thoughts are he looked offside in the builder.
The goal is given, Burnley are ahead.
West Ham's confidence very brittle.
Burnley have been the better side.
Bowen, tricking his way through,
and sneaking a shot at goal that nearly crept in.
Deflected wide from Jarrod Bowen.
Promising link-up between Wilson and him.
Port for Burnley, they hold on here until half-time.
Ooh, there's a header on goal.
I think it was Kilman up from the bat that was blocked.
Burnley looking for back-to-back away wins,
having triumphed at Wolves 3-0.
But they're under pressure here now,
coming to the end of the first half.
Opportunity to get the cross in here now through Juve,
right footed towards that back post area.
Pressure from Kilman.
Walker gets it away.
Walker was shouting at Florentino there,
who allowed the cross to come in.
Corner taken very quickly.
Somerville.
It's in! Wilson!
It hasn't come yet, and West Ham are level.
And that is what he does.
He poaches goals.
Penalty by Wilson.
He knocks Penrith up.
Callum Wilson only a second since joining the club.
How many of his 143 club career goals has he snuffled up like that?
Gambling that the ball might come to him.
Callum for Burnley would give them 11 from 11 games.
It's a really good return for promoted side.
They want more, though.
Florentino.
Anthony with the cross, looking for Flemming.
We've already seen what he can do in the air with his...
Headed goal.
And he out-leapt the defence.
West Ham can't allow crosses to come in like this.
And the attack.
Looking here for Breuer.
He's there again, Armando Breuer.
The penalty is strong.
So too, though, was Wan-Bissaka.
Anthony has stayed down for Burnley.
West Ham counter.
And here's Somerville.
